description: From Scottish English glom, glaum (“to grab or snatch at”), a variant of clam, claum (“to clutch, seize, grasp, reach for”), from Middle English *clammen, from Old English clæmman (“to pinch, press, inclose”), from Proto-West Germanic *klammjan. Related to clamp.

verbs.description: glom (third-person singular simple present gloms, present participle glomming, simple past and past participle glommed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, informal) To grab hold of, seize; catch, grab or latch onto.
examples: In short, blood comes through the artery (arteriole) and material gloms onto the nephron before twisting through the near (proximal) tubes, looping the loop, twisting through the distant (distal) tubes, and collecting itself at the other end.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, informal) To clump up, to seize together into a lump or conglomeration.
examples: “The oil pan cracked, the engine seized, and the internal parts glommed together.”

description: Variant of glaum, gloom (“to frown, scowl, stare at”).

verbs.description: glom (third-person singular simple present gloms, present participle glomming, simple past and past participle glommed)
